texts.shortText:
Bamboo worms are very easily identified to group, as the body is long, soft and cylindrical and the segments greatly elongated, each bearing short rows of longish hooked setae. The body thus resembles a length of bamboo. Each species has a fixed number of segments.

The head in this genus has an arched dorsal crest and is extended into a short point, but has no other appendages. The last segment is in the form of a distinctive frilly, flared funnel with a ridge part way along it, and the anus opens within the funnel. There are several regional species and these are difficult to distinguish from one another.

Global: The group is widespread, but as this entry is not to species level, global distribution cannot be given.

Local/Regional: Members of genus found across region.

Burrow head down into the sediments and secrete a friable tube made out of pieces of shell and sand cemented together with a membranous lining. The anal cone blocks the entrance to the tube.  Usually found attached to the sides of boulders that are buried in or are lying on sand.
Ingest sand from which they digest organic particles, including protists and bacteria.

Little is known about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that sperm and eggs are released into the water column and that these develop into planktonic larvae. Have good powers of regeneration and if segments are lost the exact correct number of segments typical of each species is regenerated.

Easy to identify to group, but there are several species that can only be distinguished by microscopic examination.

The genus Euclymene is similar in overall body form, but the head consists of a flat plate with a raised rim. Again there are several species in that genus which make sandy tubes in sand or in sand-inundated areas on rocky shores.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 621).
